title: In the English language, when do you use s’ and ‘s? - Quora

response.answer_text: This seems to get just about everyone on social media pages these days. I’ve written about it before, but can never find any of my answers on Quora… Perhaps some examples rather than quote grammar, which I can’t do anyway… The sentence “We are going to the Smith’s house tonight for tea” has the apostrophe ‘s’ because their name is Smith and the apostrophe ‘s’ denotes ownership - in this case their house. However “We are going to the Roberts’ house tonight for tea” has the apostrophe after the ‘s’ because their name already includes an ‘s’. The apostrophe at the end in effect means “We are going to the Roberts’s house tonight for tea”, though that’s a bit clunky, even though some people would pronounce the double ‘s’ in this case as it’s someone’s name. It is also relevant when we are talking about plurals. “The horse’s tail is twitching” means there is only one horse - and one tail of course. “The horses’ tails are twitching” however shows that there are more than one horse - and tails - so in this case one wouldn’t pronounce it as horses’s! If the horses in the last example only had one stall between them, then it would be “The horses’ stall needs painting”, whereas if they all had their own, then it would be “The horses’ stalls need painting” You see evidence of the “Grocer’s apostrophe” in many shops and supermarkets in the UK, as it seems grocers are not the best users of English grammar. Examples such as “Try our fresh carrot’s today!” should have customers asking “Your fresh carrot’s what?”, but as most of the population (evidenced by the likes of FaceBook) cannot manage the appropriate grammar anyway, it’s unlikely that the customers would notice. There are others which also use inverted commas incorrectly, such as “Try our “fresh” carrot’s today!” which is even worse, and should have the customers wondering why the carrots are not actually fresh? Correct pronunciation can change completely the sense of a sentence - 40 Ridiculously Cringeworthy Mistakes That Prove Punctuation and Proofreading Matter - shows how things can go astray…

It’s a very simple rule, with only rare exceptions. ‘s is the singular possessive, even if the singular ends in s. s’ is the plural possessive, unless it’s a plural that doesn’t end in s, like children (children’s). The exception occurs in ancient classical or biblical figures’ names that end in s or es and are multisyllabic, such as Jesus (Jesus’), Moses (Moses’), Xerxes (Xerxes’), Socrates (Socrates’), Amos (Amos’),and Euripides (Eurpides’). But not Zeus (Zeus’s), because it is one syllable. And not Charles (Charles’s), because it is not an ancient classical or biblical figure’s name. That means if a surname ends in s, you still add ‘s to it, such the Roberts family. “I’m going to the Roberts’s house.” Also, if the last letter is silent, such as Descartes (pronounced day-cart), you still add ‘s, Descartes’s (pronounced day-carts).
